comment.author: 53957858@N05
comment._content: Great shot!  I don't think the photo is inverted, he's just a lefty! Everything is in the right place for a left hander, Kick on his left foot, low boy on his right, snare hand holding stick in traditional grip (in this case his right)  etc etc. A left hander will set up a kit exactly the same as a right hander, only mirror image! Take a look at the next shot in this photostream and you can see him playing this kit as it's set up in this shot and you can read the Jim Coates banners- the right way round :)

comment.author: 9102614@N03
comment._content:
The photo is more than likely inverted. While lefty drummers today do set their kits up typically as mirror images to right handed drummers, the temple blocks on top of the bass drum should follow the tuning of a keyboard. Meaning the smaller blocks go to the right and the larger to the left regardless of the player. 

Either way, this photo is awesome!

comment.author: 27309380@N06
comment._content:
@ rogue.pyjamas

Allow me to enlighten the question as to the large round symbol "sun worship" thing is. It's a gong! Gong's were all the rage in the 1920s and were almost un heard of in Jazz/dance bands by the mid 1930s. 

For all the modern music minded, in the 1920s and 30s, music was much different. It was playful, syncopated and intricate. Drummers of this era were extremely talented (I'd like to see some of today's drummers go against some of the guys of early Jazz) and one kit would differ from the next. However there were many similar things that could be found in a typical 1920s drum kit such as coconuts, cowbells, a gong, suspended symbols from thick wire mounts, chimes and a small vibraphone off to the side. 

Watching some of the early Vitaphone one reel shorts of 1929 to the early 30s one can really get a better understanding of early jazz music. :-)

I would have to say, this is a pretty elaborate kit, I've never seen such a bridge over the base drum such as this, and I'm sure that "Nerd" behind there was the life beat of the band. I'm going to see if I can dig up some recordings of this band, if they made any… what a different world it was back then… in some ways, a better one.

comment.author: 59302818@N00
comment._content:
I started playing drums with my uncles band at age 15 in 1951 and  with the exception of the 'Gong' and the 'Wheels' this was the kind of drumkit that I played.  This was in the rural Ireland of the forties and fifties when electricty had still not reached many parts of the countryside. Most of the country halls we played in had no electricity and the hall was lit by 
 'Tilley Lamps'.  I even remember that Rinso Flakes or Shredded candle wax was often spread on the dance floor instead of French Chalk.  The sound system usually consisted of one mic and two small speakers for the crooner.  The amp was operated by the battery from the car that conveyed the band to the gig. All the gear on top of the bass drum was known as 'The Traps' and the four spherical blocks were known as Skulls.  There was also a 'Wood Block with slit in each side that was known as a 'Clog Box'  aka a 'Temple Block'  
The cymbals operated by the foot were known as a 'Low Hat'  Most of the drummers in those days started life in marching bands, hence the stance of this particular drummer.  although in this case he also looks like a left handed drummer aka Cack Handed.  As a naive young lad in short trousers I asked the band leader 'When do I hit the Skullls' and he told me in no uncertain terms 'Beat the Shite out ot them when you hear the band playing a tune about a horse" lol.

comment.author: 24184828@N08
comment._content:
corncrake, that's all really interesting, thanks so much for your comment! I had never heard the term "the Skulls". And what the band leader told you about when to play them was hilarious! Interesting too, what you said about the "low hat" I'd only heard the old-fashioned low models referred to as the "low boy". 

Anyway, I never tire of learning about the evolution of the drum kit.

comment.author: 22694125@N02
comment._content: Congratulations! This is a wonderful shot! You are invited to post it to: artland

comment.author: 52118584@N04
comment._content: The idea that this shot has been 'flipped' left-to right (or is that right-to-left?) is intriguing. I believe it has been flipped, and I base that on the sign writing along the front of the frame above the bass drum. If you zoom in (CTRL+roll mouse wheel) you'll be able to discern printing there that is back-to-front. I too graduated from a marching (side) drum to a kit, and every kit I ever played had the high-hat pedal under the left foot and the bass pedal under the right. Having said all that, if the drummer is a left-hander then the photo is back-to-front. He's holding the sticks as would a right-hander. 'tis a pity he's not wearing a button-hole flower or we can't see the buttons of his jacket. They would be dead give-aways.
